parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence base currently reports no studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of actions intended to mitigate the impacts of commercial logging.
[Statement 2]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of using set-asides for primate protection within logging areas.
[Statement 3]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of reducing the size of forestry teams to employees only, excluding family members.
[Statement 4]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of certifying forest concessions and marketing products as “primate friendly”.
[Statement 5]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of implementing small and dispersed logging compartments.
[Statement 6]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of thinning trees within forests.
[Statement 7]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of providing domestic meat to logging company workers to reduce hunting.
[Statement 8]: There is no evidence from studies directly testing the effects on primate populations of avoiding slashing climbers/lianas, trees housing them, hemi-epiphytic figs, and ground vegetation.

key: _gpt-5__What is the evidence base for conservation actions designed to mitigate the impacts of commercial logging on primate populations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across multiple studies, tourism projects were associated with both potential benefits and harms for wild primates.
[Statement 2]: Tourism projects for wild primates often occurred alongside other interventions.
[Statement 3]: Mountain gorilla numbers increased after touristic projects were initiated in Rwanda, Uganda and the Republic of Congo.
[Statement 4]: One tourism project site for mountain gorillas saw a 22% rise in immature gorillas and a 30% decline in snares.
[Statement 5]: A black howler monkey population in Belize increased by 138% over 13 years after a tourism project was implemented.
[Statement 6]: The numbers of Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys in Kenya decreased despite a tourism project.
[Statement 7]: An intensive tourism project for Tibetan macaques in China that included food provisioning and range restrictions increased the primates' stress levels.
[Statement 8]: Following the intensive tourism project for Tibetan macaques in China, infant mortality for the macaques reached 100% in some years.
[Statement 9]: Following a tourism project in Madagascar, population size, body size, and/or group size declined for two lemur species.
[Statement 10]: Following a tourism project in Madagascar, one lemur species increased.
[Statement 11]: Mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years while being visited by researchers and visitors wearing face-masks, keeping safety distances, and restricting visits to healthy individuals, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of promoting mammal-related ecotourism on mammal populations.

key: _gpt-5__What are the documented benefits and harms of running tourism projects focused on wild primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The majority of reintroduced chimpanzees survived for at least 1–5 years in Guinea and the Republic of Congo.
[Statement 2]: The survival of reintroduced chimpanzees in Guinea and the Republic of Congo occurred alongside other interventions.
[Statement 3]: An individual chimpanzee repeatedly returned to human settlements in Uganda.
[Statement 4]: A reintroduced chimpanzee was reunited with its mother in Senegal.
[Statement 5]: The majority of reintroduced orangutans survived in Malaysia.
[Statement 6]: A reintroduced orangutan population declined over 33 years in a controlled study.
[Statement 7]: Primate population increases were reported in Belize five years post-reintroduction.
[Statement 8]: Primate population declines were reported in Thailand post-reintroduction.
[Statement 9]: Survival of reintroduced primates was variable across different sites.
[Statement 10]: In several countries, a minority of reintroduced primates survived for at least 15 weeks to 7 years.
[Statement 11]: In other countries, a majority of reintroduced primates survived for at least 2 months to 1 year.
[Statement 12]: Reintroduced primates showed diets and behaviors similar to wild primates of the same species in controlled studies in Madagascar and Indonesia.
[Statement 13]: A reintroduced muriqui rejoined a wild group in Brazil.

key: _gpt-5__What are the typical outcomes when primates are reintroduced into habitats where the same species is already present?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For some primate group reintroductions, post-release survival has been reported to be at least 15 weeks to seven years.
[Statement 2]: In many cases, translocated or reintroduced primates have been reported to survive between two and thirty months.
[Statement 3]: Quarantined orangutans have been observed to survive for over three months post-release.
[Statement 4]: Reintroduced black lion tamarins have been observed to survive for at least four months.
[Statement 5]: Some orangutans have been observed to survive the first three months post-release.
[Statement 6]: Chimpanzees have been observed to survive for over one to five years post-release.
[Statement 7]: Reintroduced gorillas have been observed to survive for more than 10 years following quarantine.
[Statement 8]: A translocated olive baboon population survived for 16 years when veterinary screening and other interventions were used.
[Statement 9]: Primate populations in Madagascar and India have persisted for 4 to 55 years after group reintroductions.
[Statement 10]: One orangutan population persisted over a 40-year period despite quarantine.
[Statement 11]: One orangutan population decreased by 33% over a 40-year period despite quarantine.

key: _gpt-5__For what length of time have translocated primate populations been observed to survive post-release?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence specific to primates shows that installing rope or pole (canopy) bridges has facilitated crossings for arboreal primates.
[Statement 2]: In one case, the installation of rope or pole (canopy) bridges led to a population increase for arboreal primates.
[Statement 3]: Black lion tamarins and capuchins used a pole bridge to cross a road.
[Statement 4]: A black howler monkey population increased after pole bridges were installed over man-made gaps.
[Statement 5]: Six monitored lemur species used bridges to cross roads and pipelines.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that directly tested the effects of green bridges (overpasses) on primate populations.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Ensuring researchers and tourists are up-to-date with vaccinations is an identified action to reduce disease transmission risk from humans to wild primates.
[Statement 2]: Ensuring researchers and tourists do not visit wild primates when unwell is an identified action to reduce disease transmission risk from humans to wild primates.
[Statement 3]: One before-and-after study reported mountain gorilla numbers increased by 168% over 41 years under health measures for visitors, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 4]: A controlled study found a reintroduced orangutan population decreased by 33% over 33 years despite staff and volunteer medical checks, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 5]: Limiting the time researchers and tourists spend with habituated animals was associated with reintroduced Sumatran orangutans behaving more like wild orangutans in one controlled study.
[Statement 6]: Limiting the time researchers and tourists spend with habituated animals was associated with mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
[Statement 7]: Wearing face-masks by visitors and researchers was reported alongside the successful reunion of a confiscated young chimpanzee with its mother in Uganda in one study.
[Statement 8]: The use of face-masks by visitors and researchers was reported alongside mountain gorilla numbers increasing by 168% over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
[Statement 9]: Keeping a safety distance from habituated animals was reported with most reintroduced chimpanzees surviving over five years in one before-and-after study.
[Statement 10]: A 33% decline in reintroduced orangutans over 31 years was reported in one controlled study despite distance rules.
[Statement 11]: Keeping a safety distance from habituated animals was reported with a 168% increase in mountain gorillas over 41 years in one before-and-after study.
[Statement 12]: Additional proposed actions with no direct quantitative evidence found include avoiding contact between wild primates and human-raised primates.
[Statement 13]: Implementing quarantine for people arriving at and leaving research and tourism sites is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
[Statement 14]: Implementing health programmes for local communities is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
[Statement 15]: Not allowing people to consume food where primates can view the people is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
[Statement 16]: Wearing gloves when handling primate food or tool items is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
[Statement 17]: Installing primate-proof garbage bins is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.
[Statement 18]: Controlling potential ‘reservoir’ species to reduce pathogen sources is a proposed action with no direct quantitative evidence found.

key: _gpt-5__What actions can be taken at research and tourism sites to reduce the risk of disease transmission from humans to wild primates?
_gpt-5__What are the comparative outcomes of different supplementary feeding strategies for primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with increases in a chimpanzee population after two months of feeding in Tanzania.
[Statement 2]: Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with a decline in a golden lion tamarin population after one year in Brazil.
[Statement 3]: Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with the retrieval and reintegration of an abandoned infant muriqui in Brazil.
[Statement 4]: Providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with minority survival in some primate reintroductions in Brazil, Madagascar and South Africa.
[Statement 5]: In other cases, providing supplementary food for a limited period was associated with majority survival of chimpanzees in Guinea, primates in Gabon, South Africa and Vietnam, and lowland gorillas in Gabon and the Republic of Congo.
[Statement 6]: Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with the majority survival of introduced chimpanzees for at least five years in the Republic of Congo.
[Statement 7]: Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with the survival of wild olive baboons for at least 17 years post-translocation in Kenya.
[Statement 8]: Providing supplementary food only during resource-scarce periods was associated with black-and-white ruffed lemurs maintaining a diet similar to wild individuals in Madagascar.
[Statement 9]: In captive-focused feeding strategies, providing cut branches led captive gorillas in the Netherlands and Germany to use processing skills seen in wild gorillas.
[Statement 10]: Increasing the number of feeds per day increased the time spent feeding in chimpanzees.
[Statement 11]: Increasing the number of feeds per day increased hair eating in baboons in Japan and the USA.

[Statement 1]: Evidence on permanent human presence shows mixed outcomes across primate contexts.
[Statement 2]: A study in Kenya reported declines in Tana River red colobus and crested mangabeys despite the permanent presence of reserve staff.
[Statement 3]: A study in Thailand found a reintroduced lar gibbon population declined over three years under permanent staff presence.
[Statement 4]: A study in Belize found black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after permanent staff were introduced.
[Statement 5]: Studies in Congo reported that most reintroduced central chimpanzees survived over five years when accompanied by reserve staff.
[Statement 6]: Studies in Gabon reported that most reintroduced western lowland gorillas survived over nine months when accompanied by reserve staff.
[Statement 7]: Habituation of primates to human presence has shown varied results for conservation.
[Statement 8]: An introduced golden lion tamarin population declined after one year of habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 9]: Most introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs survived over 30 months following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 10]: Most introduced diademed sifakas survived over 30 months following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 11]: A mountain gorilla population increased over 41 years following habituation to human presence, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 12]: Continuous on-site veterinary monitoring was associated with a 168% increase in mountain gorilla population size over 41 years, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 13]: Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with no gorillas being killed over 21 months, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 14]: Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with increased numbers of immature gorillas, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 15]: Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with the growth of a hoolock gibbon population, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 16]: Training anti-poaching ranger patrols was associated with a three-year period with no incidents of primate poaching, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 17]: Implementing monitoring and surveillance systems to guide law enforcement in Nigeria was followed by increased observations of gorillas and chimpanzees.

key: _gpt-5__How does a permanent human presence at a site influence the success of primate conservation efforts?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence directly on relocating primates is limited.
[Statement 2]: One source reported no studies quantifying the effects of relocating primates to non-residential areas.
[Statement 3]: A reported potential benefit of relocating problem primates is survival at or near non-residential release sites.
[Statement 4]: Translocated rhesus monkeys in India survived for at least four years at or near non-residential release sites.
[Statement 5]: Translocated western lowland gorillas in the Republic of Congo and Gabon survived for at least four years at or near non-residential release sites.
[Statement 6]: Relocated crop-raiding olive baboons in Kenya had long-term survival comparable to non-translocated populations after 16 years.
[Statement 7]: Potential drawbacks from broader mammal translocations include lower survival after translocation compared to non-translocated animals.
[Statement 8]: Translocated grizzly bears, some deer, and most translocated Amur tigers showed lower survival rates after translocation.
[Statement 9]: A potential drawback of translocation is individuals returning to capture locations and/or continuing nuisance behavior.
[Statement 10]: Translocated bears sometimes repeatedly return to capture locations and continue nuisance behavior.
[Statement 11]: One case of leopard translocation led to increased attacks on humans and livestock.
[Statement 12]: One study found translocated brown bears occurred less often inside high-conflict areas than non-translocated bears.
[Statement 13]: Nearly half of translocated nuisance black bears returned to their capture sites.
[Statement 14]: Returns to capture sites were less likely when younger bears were moved farther away.
[Statement 15]: Returns to capture sites were less likely when bears were moved across barriers.

key: _gpt-5__To manage human-wildlife conflict in residential areas, what are the benefits and potential drawbacks of relocating primates?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated, before-and-after study in India found that translocated ‘problem’ rhesus monkeys, alongside other interventions, survived and remained at release sites for at least four years.
[Statement 2]: A controlled, before-and-after study in Kenya showed that crop-raiding olive baboons translocated from farmland, alongside other interventions, mostly survived after 16 years.
[Statement 3]: The survival rates of the translocated olive baboons in the Kenya study were similar to non-translocated populations.
[Statement 4]: A before-and-after, site comparison study in the Republic of Congo and Gabon found that 84% of relocated ‘problem’ western lowland gorillas, alongside other interventions, survived for at least four years.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the effects on primate populations for relocating primates to non-residential areas.
[Statement 6]: No evidence of effectiveness or harm is available for relocating primates to non-residential areas.

parts.text:

[Statement 2]: A review in Japan found that aggressive interactions between Japanese macaques and humans declined after prohibiting tourists from feeding monkeys.
[Statement 3]: There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from not allowing people to consume food within natural areas where primates can view them.
[Statement 4]: There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from installing ‘primate-proof’ garbage bins.
[Statement 5]: There is no evidence for effects on primate populations from removing human food waste that may potentially serve as food sources for primates.
[Statement 6]: Two before-and-after studies in Belize found black howler monkey numbers increased by 61–138% over 3–13 years after a multimedia campaign or opening a museum for wildlife education, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 7]: Two before-and-after studies in Brazil and Colombia found that education programs focusing on tamarins improved attitudes and knowledge.
[Statement 8]: One study in the Republic of Congo found that large numbers of people were informed about lowland gorillas through theatre and film.
[Statement 9]: One before-and-after study in Madagascar found poaching of diademed sifakas and black and white ruffed lemurs appeared to have ceased after the distribution of conservation books in schools.
[Statement 10]: A before-and-after study in India found hoolock gibbon numbers increased by 66% over five years after an education and awareness programme was implemented alongside other interventions.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two studies reported primate population increases following regular provision of supplementary food alongside other interventions.
[Statement 2]: Two studies reported primate population declines under similar circumstances of regular supplementary food provision.
[Statement 3]: Three studies reported that the majority of primates survived with regular supplementary feeding.
[Statement 4]: One study on continuous supplementary feeding reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least one year.
[Statement 5]: One controlled study found introduced black-and-white ruffed lemurs showed different diets from a resident wild group after a year of regular supplementation.
[Statement 6]: One before-and-after study on scarce-period-only feeding reported the majority of chimpanzees survived for at least five years.
[Statement 7]: One before-and-after study reported wild olive baboons survived for at least 17 years after drought-period feeding soon after translocation.
[Statement 8]: One controlled study reported that black-and-white ruffed lemur diets were similar to wild individuals after scarce-period feeding.
[Statement 9]: One study reported a chimpanzee population increase after two months of post-reintroduction feeding.
[Statement 10]: One before-and-after study reported a golden lion tamarin population declined after one year following limited-time supplementary feeding.
[Statement 11]: One study reported an abandoned infant muriqui was retrieved by the infant's mother and rejoined the wild group after receiving limited-time supplementary feeding.
[Statement 12]: Four studies involving limited-time supplementary feeding reported that only a minority of reintroduced primates survived.
[Statement 13]: One study on limited-time supplementary feeding reported the majority of introduced chimpanzees survived for at least 27 months.
[Statement 14]: Three studies reported a majority of primates survived reintroduction while receiving limited-time supplementary feeding.
[Statement 15]: Two studies on limited-time supplementary feeding reported the majority of lowland gorillas survived for at least nine months to four years.
